Articles.Content:
While I'm aware that this has probably been said by others, and probably stabbed through, thrown down, repeatedly kicked in the head and set on fire by a minority of regular users, I feel compelled to say something.

I don't care why it happened.
I don't care when it happened.
I don't care if it had to happen.
I don't care if you think it's all much better now.
I don't especially care if anything is already being done about it.

The new forum styling is *just horrible*.

I'm an infrequent visitor to these pages, it's true, but considering the extreme eyestrain/blood loss I've endured in submitting this post alone it's likely I'll be here less than ever from here forward.

This is the first and last I'll have to say about it, since it has apparently all happened while I've been away, and any objections of mine are bound to be as penetrating as water from a duck's back.

I'm aware that my future absence is hardly likely to cause the single batting of an eyelid, but if the forum I first joined several years ago had looked like this, I would have immediately turned away. Surely that's not good for anybody?

I do hope the next time I look in (I'll give it 6 months or so) the forum won't still do its best to give me cataracts.
It is rather white. I have heard that some people have made a patch that lets you customize the look of the forums, or at the very least makes it look like the old forums.

I sincerely don't understand what's so bad about it. Virtually everything I read is written in black on white paper, so... not that different. White text on a dark background is far worse, in my opinion.

Not trashing your opinion, just don't get it.
I like the new forum. It's more mobile friendly than it used to be. A refreshment is always good from time to time. Also all those notifications about sbd quoting you is very kewl imo.

Same. I also don't get all the complaints about width. Books are taller than they are wide, and are usually white with black text. They seem to have worked pretty well for two millennia. So people saying "if it ain't broke, why fix it" are using a bit of a self-defeating argument.
